task.title: Task: Simple Array Formulas
task.shortdesc: Learn how to create simple array formulas.

context.p: In the next figure, you can see that the sum and product of two numbers are calculated a few times. This can be done with simple formulas. For example, the formula in D2 could be =A2+B2. And the formula in E2 could be =A2*B2. When copying these formulas down the correct formulas are also in D3:E4.

fig.title: Sum and product of two numbers

image.alt: Sum and product of two numbers

context.p: This calculation can also be done with array formulas. This provides no benefits here, but it is a good task to learn to work with array formulas.

step.cmd: Select area D2:D4 and type =A2:A4+B2:B4 and then press CTRL SHIFT ENTER.
step.info: Because the result of the addition is a column of three numbers, you should first select an area of three cells for the results.

fig.title: Sum of two columns with array formula

image.alt: Sum of two columns with array formula

stepresult.p: The results you see in the cells D2:D4. On the formula bar, you see Excel surrounded the formula with braces.

step.cmd: Select area E2:E4 and type =A2:A4*B2:B4 and then press CTRL SHIFT ENTER.

fig.title: Product of two columns with array formula

image.alt: Product of two columns with array formula

stepresult.p: The results you see in the cells E2:E4. On the formula bar, you see Excel surrounded the formula with braces.

example.title: Example: 1-dimensional horizontal array
example.p: In this example, a row of three numbers is multiplied by the number 4. The result is a row of three numbers. Create this example.

example.title: Example: 2-dimensional array
example.p: In this example, an array of 4 rows and 3 columns is multiplied with a column of four numbers. The result is an array of 4 rows and 3 columns. Create this example.
